titleStmt.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, August 1, 1899

bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.note: Index Bureau Dept. of State Rec'd 2 Sep '99
div1.p:
No. 33, Consular Series.
Legation of the United States,
Monrovia Liberia,
Aug. 1, 1899.

Owen L. W. Smith,
To
Hon. David J. Hill,
Assistant Secretary of State,
Washington.

No. 33. Consular Series.
Legation of the United States,
Monrovia Liberia,
Aug., 1, 1899.

Hon. David J. Hill,
Assistant Secretary of State,
Washington.

I have the honor to say, that in my No. 21, Consular, of Feb'y 28, 1899, I gave an account of the condition of the Consular Agency, at Cape Coast Castle; adding a partial report of the exports and imports; including the number of American vessels, tonnage, number of crew &c, trading between the United States and the Gold Coast Colony, from July 1, 1897, to Feb'y 1, 1899, which partial report, I have, since,
since, supplemented, by an official statistical report from the Colonial Government, from July 1, 1897, to Feb'y 1, 1899. In my No. 21, Consular, I stated that if the Department, after a careful consideration of the bulk of the trade, between the United States and the Gold Coast Colony, decided it to be sufficient to justify the continuation of the Agency, I would undertake the responsibility of making a nomination for said Agency. In fact, in the absence of a proper blank application, for office, I did make a nomination; the which I have not, since, heard from. The party, thus recommended, I have recently heard from, who informed me that he has been
been having very bad health, for several months.

After waiting, a period of five months, for a reply; and not yet, being able to know the decision of the Department, in regards to said Agency; and knowing too, that I made only temporary arrangements for the care of the archives and other property of said Agency, I have thought it my duty to ask for a more definite understanding, relative thereto.

I have the honor to be
your obedient servant;
Owen L. W. Smith,
M. R. and C. General.
